discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) feature that allows a wireless device to perform a Layer 3 roam between two separate controllers without changing the client IP address is **A. mobility tunnel**.

When a client roams from one controller to another, a mobility tunnel is established between the controllers to ensure that the client's session and IP address remain unchanged. This feature is part of Cisco's mobility architecture, which facilitates seamless roaming and maintains continuous client connectivity across different subnets and controllers.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

questions.question_text: Which Cisco WLC feature allows a wireless device to perform a Layer 3 roam between two separate controllers without changing the client IP address?

discussion.content:
From MS Copilot 
summary-address: This command is used on Autonomous System Boundary Routers (ASBRs) to summarize external routes that have been redistributed into the OSPF domain. It generates Type 5 LSAs (External LSAs).

area range: This command is used on Area Border Routers (ABRs) to summarize routes within the OSPF domain. It generates Type 3 LSAs (Summary LSAs) to advertise summarized routes between OSPF areas.

Task 1

router ospf 100
router-id 3.3.3.3
network 10.10.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
network 10.20.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
network 10.50.40.0 0.0.0.255 area 50

Task 2

router ospf 100
area 50 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0

comments.content:
R30(config)# interface Loopback0
R30(config-if)# ip address 10.0.0.1 255.255.255.255
R30(config-if)# no shutdown
R30(config-if)# exit

R30(config)# router ospf 100
R30(config-router)# router-id 10.0.0.1
R30(config-router)# network 10.10.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
R30(config-router)# network 10.20.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
R30(config-router)# network 10.50.40.0 0.0.0.255 area 50
R30(config-router)# area 50 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0
R30(config-router)# area 50 stub

Router ospf 100
area 50 stub no-summary ( area 50 must be a totally stub area, in order for R20 to not flood type3 and type5 lsa ( stub area pnly filter type 5 Lsa)

Bu t the configuration of a totaly stub/stub area need all the router in the area to be configured. So this is not the correct method. The right method is to use prefix list on R20 to filter type 3 lsa ( any) in area 50

Using stub area for area 50 can only be used if R50 also has area 50 configured as stub, otherwise the neighborship will be dropped. Totally stubby is even worse idea as it will block the type 3 LSAs as well, which is needed to summarize.

The "area 50 range x.x.x.x y.y.y.y" will generate an LSA type 3 towards area 0, which is what we want. If there are other redistributed routes on R50 advertised outside of the /18 summary route, then jmarko80 is right, and we need to filter them out with a distribute-list or a route-map.
See this article on LSA type 5 filtering:
https://networklessons.com/ospf/ospf-lsa-type-5-filtering-on-cisco-ios

discussion.content:
Configuración completa:
R30(config)# interface Loopback0
R30(config-if)# ip address 10.0.0.1 255.255.255.255
R30(config-if)# no shutdown
R30(config-if)# exit

R30(config)# router ospf 100
R30(config-router)# router-id 10.0.0.1
R30(config-router)# network 10.10.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
R30(config-router)# network 10.20.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
R30(config-router)# network 10.50.40.0 0.0.0.255 area 50
R30(config-router)# area 50 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0
R30(config-router)# area 50 stub no-summary

comments.content: may I ask why you added the "network 30.30.30.30 0.0.0.0 area 0" command?

discussion.content:
Task 1 would be:

router ospf 100
 router-id 10.0.0.1
 network 10.10.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.20.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.50.40.0 0.0.0.255 area 50
 network 30.30.30.30 0.0.0.0 area 0

Task 2 would be to add
 area 50 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0

The given answer is incorrect

Correct:
router ospf 100
area 50 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0

### Only type 3 = ABR or Area Border Router (we don't use "summary-address" for ABR)
router ospf 100
area 0 range 10.50.0.0 255.255.192.0

comments.content: actually no, if "area 50 stub" cannot be placed on the adjacent router as well, the adjaceny will fail. I believe simply the "area 50 range" command will allow just a summary LSA Type 3
do not include "no-summary" this makes it Totally Stubby which will not allow for Type 3 LSA's

discussion.content: area 50 stub no-summary

discussion.content:
To summarise between areas in OSPF you need to use the 'range' command which will generate a type 3 LSA e.g.:

R2(config)#router ospf 1
R2(config-router)#area 20 range 10.2.203.0 255.255.255.0

comments.content:
OSPF Area range vs Summary-address

1. Area range:

 - Used by Area Border Routers (ABRs) to summarize routes between OSPF areas 
 - Summarizes intra-area routes (LSA Type 1 and 2) into a single Type 3 LSA 
 - Applies to routes within the OSPF domain

2. Summary-address:

 - Used by Autonomous System Boundary Routers (ASBRs) to summarize external routes 
 - Summarizes external routes (LSA Type 5 or 7) into a single Type 5 or 7 LSA 
 - Applies to routes redistributed into OSPF from other routing protocols

2. Configure the switch port analyzer on Sw1 and mirror all VLAN 12 traffic to interface E1/3 using session number 12.

discussion.content:
I had this question, but different requirements
1. Wanted you to add a destination IP address to FlowExporter
2. Wanted a configuration of IP SLA HTTP GET with a server IP address.
3. Monitor session on the SW

R1
int e0/0
ip flow egress
ip flow ingress
ip flow monitor Q1Flow input
ip flow monitor Q1Flow output
exit
ip sla 10
icmp-echo 10.12.1.2
frequency 300
exit
ip sla schedule 10 start-time now life forever
end
copy running-config startup-config

Sw1
monitor session 12 source interface vlan 12
monitor session 12 destination interface e1/3
end
copy running-config startup-config

discussion.content:
R1# sh run | sec flow monitor
Note: This give you preconfigured flow monitor name, make a note
now, go to R1
R1(config)#int e0/0
R1(config-if)#ip flow egress
R1(config-if)#ip flow ingress
Now, activate flow monitor on interface:
R1(config-if)#ip flow monitor Q1Flow input
R1(config-if)#ip flow monitor Q1Flow output
R1(config-if)#end
R1# wr mem

SPAN Configuration:
SW1(config)# monitor session 12 source interface vlan 12
SW1(config)# monitor session 12 destination interface e1/3
SW1(config)# end
SW1# wr

Configure IP SLA ISCMP echo on R1:
R1(config)#ip sla 10
R1(config-ip-sla)#icmp-echo 10.12.1.2
R1(config-ip-sla-echo)#freqency 300
R1(config-ip-sla-echo)#end
R1#wr

comments.content:
You still need to schedule the ip sla to run.

ip sla schedule 10 start now life for-ever

For remote span, what about adding the keywords “encapsulation replicate” to the destination command? (from the OCG) without it the span session would not copy 802.1Q VLAN tags or Layer 2 protocols , like Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) bridge protocol data units (BPDUs), CDP, VTP, DTP, Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP), or Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP).
The question mentions “ALL traffic”; correct me if I’m wrong

i would add this to the config
R1(config)#ip sla schedule 10 start-time now life forever
without it the ip sla doesn't runn
awesome config. the "ip flow egress/ingress" commands are not needed as that is only for traditional netflow, not flexible netflow. --also add the commands to "start" the sla

*Ping a device.
*SSH into it if the ping is successful.
*Execute a command on the device and display the output.
